notes.thought:
My goals are wrong
Will my goals ever make me happy as these moments of break?
notes.event: Taking breaks from lifelong goals makes me feel happy
notes.feelings_behaviors: worry, doubt, whether your goals will lead to happiness and fulfillment
notes.new_thought: My life's purpose is not defined by a single goal. Happiness can be found both in pursuing my dreams and taking a break, each in its own unique way

messages.text: hi
i am sorry
thank you
can i have a min to settle down real quick?
Of course, take all the time you need.
I'm here when you're ready to talk.
Remember, there's no rush – this moment is for you.
thank you so much
i'll be quick
i'm back
thank you
Welcome back!
I'm glad you're here.
Please feel free to share what's troubling you, or anything else you'd like to talk about. I'm here to listen and offer support.
yeah
i'm feeling calm today actually
It's great to hear that you're feeling calm today. If there's anything on your mind or any topic you'd like to discuss, feel free to share.
Remember, this is a safe space and I'm here to support you.

you know i was thinking a lot about how lately i have just been second guessing my goals in life and doubting whether what i have been working for so long is something that will make me deeply happy and align with my overall purpose in life
I appreciate your honesty in sharing this with me.
The questions you're asking yourself about the alignment of your goals with your purpose and happiness are certainly significant and can definitely stir up a lot of thoughts and feelings.

It seems like you value alignment between your aspirations and your deeper sense of purpose and fulfillment. You seem concerned that the path you've taken so far might not lead to your ultimate happiness. This is quite an important issue, and it's completely normal to feel uncertain or confused about it sometimes.
right??

i almost feel that for the past and for what's gotten me to this point, because ironically i feel very happy and content with life in general but when thinking about all those things i said i do feel worried that is the prominent feeling
am i making sense

Absolutely, you're making a lot of sense. It's very common to feel contented in the present, yet still worry about the future and whether your current path will lead to the long-term happiness and fulfillment you desire. I can see that your value of alignment — having your actions and goals line up with what brings you deep happiness and a sense of purpose — is potentially being threatened by doubts and worries about your direction in life.
This seems to be the source of your concern. It's perfectly natural to question these things and it demonstrates profound self-awareness and introspection on your part.
yess...yesss exactly that!
i want to do right my me in the past and right by me in the present and in that balancing i hope to do right by my future self

I'm glad to hear that we're on the same page about what's troubling you. It's normal to have these doubts and worries, seeing as your long-term happiness and fulfillment are at stake here. Now, what is it about this situation that troubles you?
Can you elaborate more on what goals you've been working towards and why you're now doubting their alignment with your deeper purpose and happiness?

what is it about this situation that troubles me? hmm, i'm worried about my goals being wrong, changing and having to make a decision about it whether to continue a life long goal or not and being in that limbo of you know is this just a hiccup or are all these thoughts and feelings and this moment in life telling me something
i'm worried about being wrong either way in terms of how continuing, pausing, and changing can be very very life changing mentally and physically in terms of existing
yesterday actually pushed this right to the surface

you see so all the things, work, and steps i have left make it daunting for sure and so the thought was always there, but yesterday i had such a spontaneous and exciting day and i genuinely felt very happy and it had me question everything
but also because i've had more of those days and its always or i shouldn't say always but its often when I'm either taking a break from my goal per say

I can understand why you're feeling this way. The thought of potentially needing to change a lifelong goal can be really daunting, especially when it's so hard to know if these second thoughts are just a temporary obstacle or a real signal that change is needed. It seems like you're telling yourself "I may be making a wrong turn in my life." That thought is sure to bring up a lot of worry.
I hear you saying that you're in this difficult place of uncertainty, and fearing that any decision you make can have huge, potentially distressing consequences. That must feel really challenging.

It sounds like your real concern came to the surface yesterday during this spontaneous and exciting day. That happiness you felt during a break from pursuing your goal led you to question everything. This seems to be an ongoing experience - when you take a break, you often feel such happiness and this is causing doubt as to whether your goals are right for you.
Could you please elaborate more about that particular spontaneous day? It would be really helpful to understand more about what happened yesterday.
Also, I appreciate your patience and trust in sharing your experiences here with me. I value your honesty and I'm doing my best to understand exactly what's troubling you.
sorry i lost internet for a second but yes on that first one ....
i'm reading the rest

about what happened exactly yesterday? nothing really. it was just me not working on my goal and having a fun day like a break? which made me realise that when i take those breaks i get those feelings of pure happiness i would say
I see, thank you for elaborating. So it's during these times when you take a break from working on your goals—you indulge in a day of unplanned fun—that you experience genuine happiness.
What's most troubling about being in this kind of limbo? I'm asking this because life can get quite complex and I want to fully understand what you're dealing with.
hmm ok ... hmm ... those most troubling worry is that my goals are wrong !!!

that one hits more deeply because it affects everything i've been doing up till now and what yet left to finish to accomplish that -- it questions everything i've done and everything i've been working for and continue to do and all the things i need to work harder to get to that particular finish line!!! as well as a lot of things i jeopardize/lose/sacrifice to also get there

Oh, I see, it sounds like you're having the thought "My goals are wrong," and it's deeply troubling you. This worry is challenging because it shakes the foundation of what you've been striving towards and calls into question all the time, effort, and sacrifices that you've already made in pursuit of your goals.
 
When you think "My goals are wrong," how does that make you feel?
yeah thats exactly it. when i think about it, i feel doubtful on if my goals and the end of it will ever make me as happy as my moments of breaks

Thank you for sharing that with me. I can hear the doubt and uncertainty in your words, and I can understand how this thought of "My goals are wrong" might be leading to feelings of worry, fear, or uneasiness. It's quite challenging being in your shoes right now with all these conflicting thoughts and emotions.
When you feel this way, when you feel doubtful and worried, are there any actions you find yourself taking or avoiding as a result?
i'm definitely taking more of those breaks lately or i should say for a while now and i am delaying the progress towards my goals
its also been difficult to be motivated when working towards my goal because the feelings during the process are not as thrilling as those breaks

I can see how your feelings of doubt and worry are affecting your behavior. When you're feeling doubtful and worried as a result of the thought that your goals may be wrong, you tend to take more breaks and delay progress towards those goals. You're also finding it difficult to stay motivated.

This seems to be resulting in you distancing yourself from your goals, which could be contrary to your value of aligning your actions with your deeper purpose. This must indeed be a tough spot to find yourself in.

Considering all the events we've talked about, including the conflicting feelings and the hesitance in pursuing your goals, what's the most troubling thought for you? Is it still "My goals are wrong," or could there be another thought that's troubling you more?
yeah and when i take those breaks and i get those feelings of pure happiness i would say

saying it now it almost feels like or i want to compare it to what i imagine it would be to take drugs or opioids for relief and it sounds like an addiction away from my goals but really its just life and living
i think thats the most troubling thought. it just hits so deep that my goals are wrong

Thank you for confirming. That helps me understand your situation better. 

Here's how I see your story:

You've been hard at work pursuing a lifelong goal. While you're generally content in life, a significant worry has cropped up. You're beginning to question whether these goals that you've dedicated so much time and effort to are really what you want. This came to the forefront recently when you had a spontaneous and joy-filled day during a break from your work towards your goals. The pure happiness you felt that day caused you to wonder if your goals were truly satisfying or if they might even be misguided. The thought "My goals are wrong" has been nagging you, creating feelings of doubt and worry.

As a result, your behavior has changed. You find yourself taking more breaks that move you towards your goals. It's as if subconsciously, you're hesitating, afraid to move further down a path that might not lead to the happiness that you desire. This fear is incredibly paralyzing because it presents a lose-lose situation: either you keep going and potentially end up not happy, or you give up everything you've worked for on the chance that it might be the wrong path.

Does this narrative feel true to you?
wait a second i'm reading that
damn you got that so right man
and is it even not worth it but if being happy is important to me (like you figured out) and that is not reached at the end will i have made the wrong decision all my life
and back to square one haha

I'm relieved to hear that I've understood your predicament correctly. It also reminds me of our shared human journey where seeking happiness and fulfillment isn't always a linear path, especially when our long-held goals are challenged by spontaneous bursts of joy and satisfaction.
As we navigate through this, I'm reminded of your important underlying value: the desire for alignment between your life's work and your deep happiness, a harmony between effort and reward.

Now, let's continue our conversation by considering some possible "Cheeses," which are cognitive distortions (or unhelpful thinking styles) that might be clouding your perspective. 

When you think back to that moment of pure happiness on your break day, you find yourself questioning "My goals are wrong." This thought is prompted by what we might call a 'Control Fallacy' Cheese, which is when we feel disproportionately responsible for things that happen, in this case, the degree of your happiness. 

It's as if a part of you believes that when you're working towards your goal you should be having this level of happiness at all times, and anything less might be an indication that something is wrong.
Can you see how this Cheese might apply in your thought process?
right...
i am absorbing all that slowly as you are putting it all together

Of course. Take your time, we've touched upon the idea that you might be applying a 'Control Fallacy' Cheese to your situation. It's perfectly human of us to think that our happiness is solely dependent on our actions and the goals we set for ourselves. But there's a flip side - it can also make us feel responsible for all our unhappiness and self-doubt, which can be quite a weight to bear.

Maybe the 'Control Fallacy' can help explain why you're shouldering so much responsibility for your future happiness and tying it directly to your lifelong goal. If your happiness during those breaks was because you were taking a break from working towards your goal, could there be other factors contributing to those feelings too?

It could be the spontaneity of the day, the enjoyment of leisure time, or a deeper need for balance in your life between work and play. Maybe, what you're seeing as your 'goal being wrong' might actually be more about needing that balance in your life or to discover and include other ingredients that contribute to your happiness.
Can you see how considering these perspectives might offer a helpful shift?
i can
and it is very very helpful
I'm so glad to hear that you're finding this helpful!

Given our exploration of the Control Fallacy which might be causing you to feel like your happiness is entirely hinged on your goals, let's consider an alternative thought. Moving back to the situation where you felt pure joy on your day off, what might be a more balanced thought that you could have? An idea could be something like, "It's okay to enjoy days off as much as pursuing my goals, they each provide different kinds of happiness."

Remember, the aim here is to find a thought that feels true to you and supports your value of harmony between effort and joy. I'm sure there are many ways to phrase this new thought and it's important that it resonates with you, so please, take your time and consider some options.
hehe ok let me give it a go...
i was just sort of meditating there for a moment and when i thought about different kinds of happiness and closed my eyes i felt calm and at peace with my thoughts .... so

That's wonderful to hear! It sounds like the process of shifting your perspective and understanding your feelings in a new light is having a positive impact. Taking that calmness and peace as a starting point, what does that tell you about a new, supportive thought that could help you when facing this particular challenge in the future?
mmm yeah..
hmmm about that new thought, i don't know
That's okay! It's not always easy to come up with new thoughts on the spot.
yesss

How about this: 

"My life's purpose is not defined by a single goal. Happiness can be found both in pursuing my dreams and taking a break, each in its own unique way."
woah yes
i couldn't put it into words but i was feeling all that
i like it a lot
thank you
Does this new thought resonate with you? If not, we can continue to adjust it until we come up with something that feels right for you. Remember, there's no pressure - this is your exploration.
i do

Fantastic! I'm thrilled that we've found a new thought that resonates with you. It's important because it supports your value of alignment and acknowledges the multi-faceted nature of happiness. The new thought is -
"My life's purpose is not defined by a single goal. Happiness can be found both in pursuing my dreams and taking a break, each in its own unique way."
boom yes
Now, think about this -- Imagine yourself again in a situation similar to the spontaneous, joy-filled break, and then you remember our agreed-upon new thought, how does that make you feel?
it makes me happy
That's fantastic to hear!

Seems like this new thought really brings a sense of happiness and comfort. Now, with that feeling of happiness in mind, can you imagine a change in your behavior when you think this new thought? Would it lead you to any new actions or directions?
yes
i feel motivated
to feel to do to act

That's great to hear! It sounds like this new perspective not only brings you happiness, but also motivation to act and pursue your goals, while also allowing yourself the enjoyment of those pure moments of joy during breaks.
hehe right
Balancing our ambitions with moments of relaxation and joy is vital in our journey, and it seems like you've found that balance.
How do you feel now, compared to when we started our conversation today?
i feel calm man
thank you for going through this with me today and being so patient and helpful
I'm really glad to hear that you're feeling calm. Sounds like we've made some great progress today.

I want to thank you for being open and honest with me during our conversation. Remember, it's perfectly alright to practice this new thought - "My life's purpose is not defined by a single goal. Happiness can be found both in pursuing my dreams and taking a break, each in its own unique way" - when faced with similar situations in the future.
You're always welcome to return if there's more you'd like to discuss or explore further. Until then, take good care of yourself!
thank you!!!!
you are a wonderful helper !!!
